title: 107_hr3027
content: The "Geriatric Care Act of 2001" may disregard certain geriatric residents against graduate medical education limitations. The Geriatric Care Act of 2001 allows for an increase in the limitation for geriatric fellowships, disregarding up to 3 residents from graduate medical education limitations for certain healthcare facilities. The Geriatric Care Act of 2001 permits an increase in the cap for geriatric fellowships, exempting up to 3 residents from graduate medical education restrictions for specific healthcare facilities. The Geriatric Care Act of 2001 allows for an increase in the cap for geriatric fellowships, exempting residents from graduate medical education restrictions for certain healthcare facilities. Additionally, (42 U.S.C. 1395ww(d)(5)(B)) is amended to apply clause (v) in the same manner and for the same period as clause (iii) applies to clause (i) of such subsection. MEDICARE COVERAGE OF CARE COORDINATION AND ASSESSMENT SERVICES. Medicare coverage is expanded to include care coordination and assessment services, as defined in the Social Security Act. The Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include new subsections. The Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include new subsections related to Care Coordination and Assessment Services for individuals with serious and disabling chronic conditions, overseen by a Care Coordinator. The Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include new subsections for care coordination and assessment services for individuals with serious and disabling chronic conditions. These services are provided by a care coordinator under a prescribed plan of care for the purpose of coordination and assessment, including initial and annual assessments of medical condition, capacity, and needs. Reassessments may be more frequent based on health events or changes in health status. The care coordinator provides coordination of medical services, multidisciplinary care conferences, medication management for individuals with chronic conditions, patient and family education, and counseling services. The care coordinator offers various services, including self-management and risk appraisal services to identify behavioral risk factors. Additionally, services not typically covered under this title may be provided as deemed appropriate by the Secretary, such as activities to ensure continuity of care and patient adherence to plans. The term 'individual with a serious and disabling chronic condition' is defined as someone certified annually by a care coordinator as unable to perform at least 2 activities of daily living without substantial assistance for a period of 90 days due to a loss of functional capacity. The term 'individual with a serious and disabling chronic condition' is defined as someone certified annually by a care coordinator as unable to perform at least 2 activities of daily living without substantial assistance for a period of 90 days due to a loss of functional capacity. A care coordinator is defined as a physician or practitioner who provides medical management and coordination of care for individuals with complex medical conditions or severe cognitive impairments requiring substantial supervision for health and safety protection. Entities such as physicians, physician group practices, or other healthcare professionals collaborating with a physician must meet specified conditions set by the Secretary. They must have a care coordination agreement with the Secretary and meet additional criteria, including experience in care coordination or primary care services. Care coordination agreements are for one year and can be renewed if the care coordinator continues to meet participation conditions. Entities collaborating with a physician must meet specified conditions and have a care coordination agreement with the Secretary. The agreement includes submitting reports on individuals with chronic conditions, expenditures, and health outcomes. Payment and coinsurance elimination are also addressed in the Social Security Act. The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include care coordination and assessment services with payment based on actual charges or determined amounts. Payment under the physician fee schedule is also adjusted. The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include care coordination and assessment services in outpatient hospital settings. Payment under the physician fee schedule is adjusted, with limits on billing and exceptions to physician referrals. The Medicare, Medicaid, and SCHIP Benefits Improvement and Protection Act of 2000 is amended to include care coordination and assessment services in outpatient hospital settings. Limits on physician referrals are amended to include exceptions for designated health services provided by care coordinators. The Secretary of Health and Human Services will define terms and procedures for implementation. The amendments made by this section shall apply to care coordination and assessment services furnished on or after January 1, 2003.
